question_details.query: What actions can be taken to reduce predation by marine mammals at aquaculture systems?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the evidence found, several actions can be taken to reduce predation by marine mammals at aquaculture systems. Replacing anti-predator nets more frequently at salmon farms resulted in fewer salmon losses to harbour seal predation (action ID: 2774). Using acoustic devices at aquaculture systems was effective in some studies - four out of six studies found that acoustic devices reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals and South American sea lions, or reduced the number of harbour seals approaching fish cages (action ID: 2775). However, translocating mammals away from aquaculture systems was not effective, as two studies found that more than half or nearly all of Australian and New Zealand fur seals translocated away from salmon farms returned (action ID: 2776). No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of modifying aquaculture gear (action ID: 2742), modifying anti-predator nets (action ID: 2743), minimizing food waste (action ID: 2744), introducing regulations to prevent harmful deterrents (action ID: 2746), or introducing legislation to prevent intentional killing of mammals (action ID: 2745) at aquaculture systems.
summary_statements: Several actions can be taken to reduce predation by marine mammals at aquaculture systems.
Replacing anti-predator nets more frequently at salmon farms resulted in fewer salmon losses to harbour seal predation.
Using acoustic devices at aquaculture systems was effective in some studies.
Four out of six studies found that acoustic devices reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals and South American sea lions.
Four out of six studies found that acoustic devices reduced the number of harbour seals approaching fish cages.
Translocating mammals away from aquaculture systems was not effective.
Two studies found that more than half or nearly all of Australian and New Zealand fur seals translocated away from salmon farms returned.
No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of modifying aquaculture gear at aquaculture systems.
No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of modifying anti-predator nets at aquaculture systems.
No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of minimizing food waste at aquaculture systems.
No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of introducing regulations to prevent harmful deterrents at aquaculture systems.
No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of introducing legislation to prevent the intentional killing of mammals at aquaculture systems.

question_details.query: Which modifications to fishing gear are most effective at reducing marine mammal entanglement?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents shows that deploying fishing nets at different depths is effective at reducing marine mammal entanglements. One controlled study in the Arafura Sea found that fishing nets deployed 4.5 m below the water surface had fewer entanglements of dolphins than surface nets (Action 2793). Using acoustically reflective fishing gear materials can also reduce entanglements - two of three controlled studies found that fishing nets made from acoustically reflective materials (iron-oxide or barium sulfate) had fewer entanglements of harbour porpoises than conventional fishing nets, although one study found that nets made from barium sulfate did not reduce dolphin entanglements (Action 2807). The use of weakened fishing gear has not been evaluated in studies for marine mammal populations (Action 2797). Other gear modifications such as establishing move-on rules for fishing vessels when mammals are encountered can reduce marine mammal mortality - a before-and-after study in the Great Australian Bight found that introducing measures to delay or relocate fishing if dolphins were encountered resulted in fewer short-beaked common dolphins being encircled and killed (Action 2790).
summary_statements: Deploying fishing nets at different depths is effective at reducing marine mammal entanglements.
Fishing nets deployed 4.5 m below the water surface in the Arafura Sea had fewer entanglements of dolphins than surface nets.
Using acoustically reflective fishing gear materials can reduce entanglements.
Fishing nets made from acoustically reflective materials like iron-oxide or barium sulfate had fewer entanglements of harbour porpoises than conventional fishing nets.
Nets made from barium sulfate did not reduce dolphin entanglements.
The use of weakened fishing gear has not been evaluated in studies for marine mammal populations.
Establishing move-on rules for fishing vessels when marine mammals are encountered can reduce marine mammal mortality.
Introducing measures in the Great Australian Bight to delay or relocate fishing if dolphins were encountered resulted in fewer short-beaked common dolphins being encircled and killed.

question_details.query: What are the population-level effects of legally protecting marine mammal species or their habitats?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the evidence found, legally protecting marine mammal species and their habitats shows several population-level effects. For habitat protection specifically, four studies found mixed but generally positive effects: Mediterranean monk seal populations increased after eight years of island protection, bottlenose dolphin populations maintained similar sizes before and after habitat protection, Hector's dolphins showed higher survival rates after coastal area protection, and human-caused strandings decreased while overall strandings remained similar after area protection. For hunting prohibitions, four of five studies found that abundance increased after hunting bans: harbour seals and humpback whales increased over 7-30 years, and 10 of 12 baleen whale populations showed significant increases during 7-21 years after protective legislation. However, no studies were found evaluating the direct effects of legally protecting marine mammal species themselves, and one study found no significant change in mature male sperm whale numbers 31 years after hunting prohibition.
summary_statements: Legally protecting marine mammal species and their habitats shows several population-level effects.
Studies on habitat protection for marine mammals found mixed but generally positive effects.
Mediterranean monk seal populations increased after eight years of island protection.
Bottlenose dolphin populations maintained similar sizes before and after habitat protection.
Hector's dolphins showed higher survival rates after coastal area protection.
Human-caused strandings decreased after area protection.
Overall strandings remained similar after area protection.
Four out of five studies found that the abundance of marine mammals increased after hunting bans.
The populations of harbour seals and humpback whales increased over a period of 7 to 30 years after hunting bans.
Ten of twelve baleen whale populations showed significant increases during the 7 to 21 years after protective legislation was enacted.
No studies were found that evaluated the direct effects of legally protecting marine mammal species themselves.
One study found no significant change in the number of mature male sperm whales 31 years after a hunting prohibition.

question_details.query: What is the state of the evidence for interventions aimed at reducing lethal vessel collisions with marine mammals?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The evidence base for interventions to reduce lethal vessel collisions with marine mammals is extremely limited. Only one intervention type has been evaluated in any studies: setting and enforcing vessel speed limits. Two before-and-after studies examined this intervention - one in the Indian River estuarine system (USA) and one in the North Atlantic Ocean (USA). The Indian River study found similar numbers of manatee deaths before and after vessel speed limits were set in 'zones', but fewer deaths after speed limits were set and enforced in all areas. The North Atlantic study found that setting vessel speed limits during specific periods in key habitats resulted in fewer North Atlantic right whale deaths caused by collisions. All other intervention types have no evidence base whatsoever - no studies were found for: using observers on board vessels, diverting shipping routes, implementing regulations, providing vessel operator training, modifying vessels, using remote detection tools, using real-time automated detection tools, or using technology and reporting systems.
summary_statements: The evidence base for interventions to reduce lethal vessel collisions with marine mammals is extremely limited.
Setting and enforcing vessel speed limits is the only intervention type that has been evaluated in any studies.
Two before-and-after studies have examined the intervention of setting and enforcing vessel speed limits.
One study on vessel speed limits was conducted in the Indian River estuarine system in the USA.
One study on vessel speed limits was conducted in the North Atlantic Ocean in the USA.
The Indian River study found that the number of manatee deaths was similar before and after vessel speed limits were set in 'zones'.
The Indian River study found there were fewer manatee deaths after speed limits were set and enforced in all areas.
The North Atlantic study found that setting vessel speed limits during specific periods in key habitats resulted in fewer deaths of North Atlantic right whales caused by collisions.
All other intervention types for reducing lethal vessel collisions with marine mammals have no evidence base.
No studies were found for the intervention of using observers on board vessels.
No studies were found for the intervention of diverting shipping routes.
No studies were found for the intervention of implementing regulations.
No studies were found for the intervention of providing vessel operator training.
No studies were found for the intervention of modifying vessels.
No studies were found for the intervention of using remote detection tools.
No studies were found for the intervention of using real-time automated detection tools.
No studies were found for the intervention of using technology and reporting systems.

question_details.query: How do the outcomes of translocating marine mammals vary depending on the conservation goal, based on studies from the Pacific and Tasman Sea regions?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on studies from the Pacific and Tasman Sea regions, translocation outcomes for marine mammals vary significantly depending on conservation goals. In the North Pacific Ocean, studies on Hawaiian monk seal translocations for population re-establishment showed positive outcomes: 50-83% survival rates for translocated pups, with survival rates similar to or greater than non-translocated pups. More than a quarter of translocated seals reproduced, and they exhibited similar dispersal behavior to native-born pups. In contrast, studies in the Tasman Sea focused on conflict reduction showed poor outcomes: when Australian and New Zealand fur seals were translocated away from salmon farms, more than half or nearly all returned to the original sites, making this approach ineffective for reducing human-wildlife conflict.
summary_statements: Based on studies from the Pacific and Tasman Sea regions, translocation outcomes for marine mammals vary significantly depending on conservation goals.
In the North Pacific Ocean, studies on Hawaiian monk seal translocations for population re-establishment showed positive outcomes.
Translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups had 50-83% survival rates.
The survival rates for translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups were similar to or greater than non-translocated pups.
More than a quarter of translocated Hawaiian monk seals reproduced.
Translocated Hawaiian monk seals exhibited similar dispersal behavior to native-born pups.
Studies in the Tasman Sea focused on conflict reduction showed poor outcomes.
When Australian and New Zealand fur seals were translocated away from salmon farms, more than half or nearly all of the seals returned to the original sites.
Translocating Australian and New Zealand fur seals away from salmon farms was an ineffective approach for reducing human-wildlife conflict.

question_details.query: What is the evidence for the long-term survival of marine mammals following rescue or rehabilitation and release?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from 27 studies on marine mammal rehabilitation and release shows variable long-term survival outcomes. Twenty-one studies with post-release monitoring found that 10-100% of dolphins, porpoises, whales, seals, sea lions and manatees survived after being released following rehabilitation, with monitoring periods ranging from three days to five years. One controlled study found that at least 25% of California sea lions treated for toxic algae poisoning and released back into the wild died or had to be euthanized. Reproductive success was demonstrated by one study showing that more than 25% of rehabilitated and released Hawaiian monk seals reproduced. Eleven studies on rescue and release of stranded or trapped marine mammals found survival rates of 17-100% during post-release monitoring periods ranging from three weeks to three years. These studies included evidence that rescued and released common bottlenose dolphins were observed with calves one year later, and that Hawaiian monk seal rescue and release, along with other interventions, resulted in more than 25% of the seals surviving and reproducing. Behavioural evidence from three controlled studies showed that rehabilitated and released harbour porpoises and harbour seals had similar movements and behaviours to wild mammals in two of the studies, while one study found that California sea lions treated for toxic algae poisoning showed altered behavior compared to wild sea lions.
summary_statements: Evidence from 27 studies on marine mammal rehabilitation and release shows variable long-term survival outcomes.
Twenty-one studies with post-release monitoring found that 10-100% of dolphins, porpoises, whales, seals, sea lions and manatees survived after being released following rehabilitation.
The monitoring periods for the twenty-one studies on rehabilitated marine mammals ranged from three days to five years.
One controlled study found that at least 25% of California sea lions treated for toxic algae poisoning and released back into the wild died or had to be euthanized.
A study demonstrated that more than 25% of rehabilitated and released Hawaiian monk seals reproduced.
Eleven studies on the rescue and release of stranded or trapped marine mammals found survival rates of 17-100%.
The post-release monitoring periods in the eleven studies on stranded or trapped marine mammals ranged from three weeks to three years.
Studies on rescued and released marine mammals found that rescued and released common bottlenose dolphins were observed with calves one year later.
Hawaiian monk seal rescue and release, along with other interventions, resulted in more than 25% of the seals surviving and reproducing.
Two controlled studies showed that rehabilitated and released harbour porpoises and harbour seals had similar movements and behaviours to wild mammals.
One study found that California sea lions treated for toxic algae poisoning showed altered behavior compared to wild sea lions.

question_details.query: What actions are available to reduce human-wildlife conflict at commercial fisheries in riverine systems?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Several actions are available to reduce human-wildlife conflict at commercial fisheries in riverine systems. Acoustic devices deployed on moorings can reduce harbour seal predation on migrating juvenile salmon (action ID 2816). Anti-predator nets around aquaculture systems can be replaced or repaired more frequently to reduce salmon losses to harbour seal predation (action ID 2774). Barriers such as 'cork line' barriers can be installed at wild fisheries, though one study found this did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon (action ID 2824). Switching off artificial lighting at wild fisheries is another option tested, but one study found it did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon (action ID 2825). Translocating mammals away from aquaculture systems has been attempted, but studies found that more than half or nearly all of translocated Australian and New Zealand fur seals returned (action ID 2776). Modifying aquaculture gear and anti-predator nets are potential actions, though no studies have evaluated their effectiveness yet (action IDs 2742, 2743).
summary_statements: Several actions are available to reduce human-wildlife conflict at commercial fisheries in riverine systems.
Acoustic devices deployed on moorings can reduce harbour seal predation on migrating juvenile salmon.
Anti-predator nets around aquaculture systems can be replaced or repaired more frequently to reduce salmon losses to harbour seal predation.
Barriers such as 'cork line' barriers can be installed at wild fisheries.
One study found that installing 'cork line' barriers did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon.
Switching off artificial lighting at wild fisheries is a tested option to reduce human-wildlife conflict.
One study found that switching off artificial lighting did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon.
Translocating mammals away from aquaculture systems has been attempted.
Studies found that more than half or nearly all of translocated Australian and New Zealand fur seals returned.
Modifying aquaculture gear and anti-predator nets are potential actions to reduce human-wildlife conflict.
No studies have evaluated the effectiveness of modifying aquaculture gear and anti-predator nets.

question_details.query: What is the evidence for the success of interventions like translocation and rehabilitation for Hawaiian monk seals in the North Pacific Ocean?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Studies found that 50-83% of translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups survived for at least one year. Translocated seal pups had similar survival rates to non-translocated pups born at release sites, and greater survival rates than non-translocated pups remaining at the original site. Translocated pups exhibited similar dispersal times to non-translocated seal pups born at release sites. More than a quarter of translocated Hawaiian monk seals reproduced after translocation combined with other survival interventions. More than a quarter of rehabilitated and released Hawaiian monk seals successfully reproduced. More than a quarter of seals survived after translocation when implemented along with at least seven other interventions to enhance survival.
summary_statements: Studies found that 50-83% of translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups survived for at least one year.
Translocated seal pups had similar survival rates to non-translocated pups born at release sites.
Translocated seal pups had greater survival rates than non-translocated pups remaining at the original site.
Translocated pups exhibited similar dispersal times to non-translocated seal pups born at release sites.
More than a quarter of translocated Hawaiian monk seals reproduced after translocation combined with other survival interventions.
More than a quarter of rehabilitated and released Hawaiian monk seals successfully reproduced.
More than a quarter of seals survived after translocation when implemented along with at least seven other interventions to enhance survival.

question_details.query: What are the non-lethal alternatives for managing marine mammal presence and predation at aquaculture facilities, and how effective are they?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Non-lethal alternatives for managing marine mammal presence and predation at aquaculture facilities include acoustic devices, translocation, and physical barrier modifications. Acoustic devices at aquaculture systems showed mixed effectiveness: four of six studies found they reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals, and South American sea lions, or reduced the number of harbour seals approaching fish cages, while two studies found they did not reduce harbour seal predation or bottlenose dolphin presence around fin-fish farms. Replacing anti-predator nets more frequently at salmon farms resulted in fewer salmon losses to harbour seal predation. Translocating mammals away from aquaculture systems was ineffective, with more than half or nearly all of Australian and New Zealand fur seals translocated away from salmon farms returning to the area. No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of modifying anti-predator nets, modifying aquaculture gear, or minimizing food waste at aquaculture systems.
summary_statements: Non-lethal alternatives for managing marine mammal presence and predation at aquaculture facilities include acoustic devices, translocation, and physical barrier modifications.
Acoustic devices at aquaculture systems showed mixed effectiveness.
Some studies found that acoustic devices reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals, and South American sea lions.
Some studies found that acoustic devices reduced the number of harbour seals approaching fish cages.
Other studies found that acoustic devices did not reduce harbour seal predation around fin-fish farms.
Other studies found that acoustic devices did not reduce bottlenose dolphin presence around fin-fish farms.
Replacing anti-predator nets more frequently at salmon farms resulted in fewer salmon losses to harbour seal predation.
Translocating mammals away from aquaculture systems was ineffective.
More than half or nearly all of Australian and New Zealand fur seals translocated away from salmon farms returned to the area.
No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of modifying anti-predator nets at aquaculture systems.
No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of modifying aquaculture gear.
No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of minimizing food waste at aquaculture systems.

question_details.query: What are the most beneficial non-lethal methods for reducing human-wildlife conflict at wild fisheries involving seals?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Based on the available evidence, several non-lethal methods have been tested for reducing seal predation at wild fisheries. The most effective approaches include:

Acoustic devices have shown significant promise across multiple studies. Deploying acoustic devices on moorings (Action 2816) reduced the number of harbour seals feeding on migrating juvenile salmon in the Puntledge River in Canada. At aquaculture systems (Action 2775), acoustic devices reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals, and South American sea lions. Using acoustic devices on fishing gear (Action 2808) reduced seal damage to fish catches and fishing nets in multiple controlled studies.

Physical gear modifications have also proven effective. Modifying fishing pots and traps to exclude mammals (Action 2822) with wire grids or steel bars, along with strengthened netting, reduced damage to salmon catches by grey and harbour seals. Installing steel rods or metal frames on fishing pots and traps also reduced the number of grey and harbour seals that entered or became trapped in pots.

Electric deterrents showed positive results in one controlled study (Action 2818), where using an electric current on a fishing net reduced Pacific harbour seal predation on salmon catches.

Less effective methods included switching off artificial lighting at wild fisheries (Action 2825) and installing cork line barriers (Action 2824), both of which failed to deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery. Playing predator calls (Action 2817) was ineffective at deterring Cape fur seals. Visual deterrents and acoustically reflective objects showed mixed or no effects on marine mammals.
summary_statements: Several non-lethal methods have been tested for reducing seal predation at wild fisheries.
Acoustic devices have shown significant promise across multiple studies for reducing seal predation.
Deploying acoustic devices on moorings reduced the number of harbour seals feeding on migrating juvenile salmon in the Puntledge River in Canada.
At aquaculture systems, acoustic devices reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals, and South American sea lions.
Using acoustic devices on fishing gear reduced seal damage to fish catches and fishing nets in multiple controlled studies.
Physical gear modifications have proven effective for reducing seal predation.
Modifying fishing pots and traps to exclude mammals with wire grids or steel bars reduced damage to salmon catches by grey and harbour seals.
Using strengthened netting on fishing pots and traps reduced damage to salmon catches by grey and harbour seals.
Installing steel rods or metal frames on fishing pots and traps reduced the number of grey and harbour seals that entered or became trapped in the pots.
Electric deterrents showed positive results in one controlled study.
Using an electric current on a fishing net reduced Pacific harbour seal predation on salmon catches.
Switching off artificial lighting at wild fisheries failed to deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery.
Installing cork line barriers failed to deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery.
Playing predator calls was ineffective at deterring Cape fur seals.
Visual deterrents showed mixed or no effects on marine mammals.
Acoustically reflective objects showed mixed or no effects on marine mammals.

question_details.query: Besides acoustic deterrents, what alternative physical modifications can be made to fishing gear to reduce porpoise and dolphin entanglement?
What management actions can reduce disturbance to marine mammals from tourism and recreational activities?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the action documents found, management actions that can reduce disturbance to marine mammals from tourism and recreational activities include: (1) Introducing and enforcing regulations for marine mammal watching tours (Action 2838) - studies showed that when whale-watching vessels followed approach regulations, fewer whales changed their behaviours or avoided vessels compared to when regulations were not followed, and fewer Guiana dolphins displayed negative behaviours when tour boats followed regulations; (2) Setting limits or prohibiting feeding of marine mammals by tourists (Action 2845) - one study found that after limits were set on feeding, the survival of bottlenose dolphin calves increased to match those of non-fed mothers; (3) Training tourist guides to minimize disturbance (Action 2840) - one study in Alaska found fewer harbour seals were disturbed during kayak excursions after guides received training; and (4) Limiting vessel speeds (Action 3531) - though studies focused on reptiles, evidence suggests lower vessel speeds cause fewer injuries and allow animals more opportunity to flee from approaching vessels.
summary_statements: Management actions that can reduce disturbance to marine mammals from tourism and recreational activities include introducing and enforcing regulations for marine mammal watching tours.
Studies showed that when whale-watching vessels followed approach regulations, fewer whales changed their behaviours or avoided vessels compared to when regulations were not followed.
Fewer Guiana dolphins displayed negative behaviours when tour boats followed regulations.
Setting limits or prohibiting the feeding of marine mammals by tourists can reduce disturbance.
One study found that after limits were set on feeding, the survival of bottlenose dolphin calves increased to match the survival of calves from non-fed mothers.
Training tourist guides to minimize disturbance is a management action that can reduce harm to marine mammals.
One study in Alaska found fewer harbour seals were disturbed during kayak excursions after guides received training.
Limiting vessel speeds is a management action to protect marine wildlife.
Evidence suggests lower vessel speeds cause fewer injuries to animals.
Lower vessel speeds allow animals more opportunity to flee from approaching vessels.

question_details.query: What are the documented effects of translocating marine mammals for different conservation purposes?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The documented effects of translocating marine mammals for conservation purposes are primarily focused on population re-establishment and boosting efforts. Four studies evaluated translocation of Hawaiian monk seals to re-establish or boost native populations in the North Pacific Ocean. These studies demonstrate varying outcomes: survival rates showed that 50-83% of translocated seal pups survived for at least one year, with rehabilitated and translocated pups showing similar survival rates (52%) [Action ID: 2930]. When compared to non-translocated populations, translocated seal pups had similar survival rates to those born at release sites or showed greater survival rates than pups remaining at original sites [Action ID: 2930]. Reproductive success was also documented, with more than a quarter of translocated seals reproducing following interventions that included rehabilitation and survival enhancement measures [Action ID: 2930]. Additionally, translocated seal pups exhibited similar dispersal behaviors to non-translocated pups born at release sites [Action ID: 2930]. Currently, no studies have been found documenting effects for other conservation translocation purposes such as moving mammals before impactful activities, relocating following oil spills, or translocating to reduce disease exposure [Action IDs: 2931, 2872, 2859].
summary_statements: The documented effects of translocating marine mammals for conservation purposes are primarily focused on population re-establishment and boosting efforts.
Four studies evaluated the translocation of Hawaiian monk seals to re-establish or boost native populations in the North Pacific Ocean.
Studies on Hawaiian monk seal translocation demonstrate varying outcomes.
Survival rates showed that 50-83% of translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups survived for at least one year.
Rehabilitated and translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups showed similar survival rates of 52%.
When compared to non-translocated populations, translocated seal pups had similar survival rates to pups born at release sites.
Translocated seal pups showed greater survival rates than pups remaining at original sites.
More than a quarter of translocated seals reproduced following interventions that included rehabilitation and survival enhancement measures.
Translocated seal pups exhibited similar dispersal behaviors to non-translocated pups born at release sites.
Currently, no studies have been found documenting effects of moving mammals before impactful activities.
No studies have been found documenting the effects of relocating marine mammals following oil spills.
No studies have been found documenting the effects of translocating marine mammals to reduce disease exposure.

question_details.query: What is the state of the evidence regarding actions to reduce pollution from land-based agricultural and municipal sources affecting marine and freshwater mammals?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The current state of evidence regarding actions to reduce pollution from land-based agricultural and municipal sources affecting marine and freshwater mammals shows a significant knowledge gap. No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of treating wastewater from intensive livestock holdings (Action ID: 2880), reducing pesticide, herbicide or fertilizer use (Action ID: 2879), establishing riparian buffers to reduce pollutant runoff (Action ID: 2882), creating artificial wetlands to reduce effluent reaching water bodies (Action ID: 2881), setting or improving minimum sewage treatment standards (Action ID: 2867), limiting storm wastewater overflow (Action ID: 2868), or establishing aquaculture to extract nutrients from agricultural runoffs (Action ID: 2883) on marine and freshwater mammal populations. Similarly, no studies were found evaluating the regulation of agrichemical use (Action ID: 2198) or limiting storm wastewater overflow (Action ID: 2181) specifically for marine mammals. The lack of studies means there is currently no evidence to indicate whether these pollution reduction actions are effective or have any harmful impacts on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
summary_statements: The current state of evidence regarding actions to reduce pollution from land-based agricultural and municipal sources affecting marine and freshwater mammals shows a significant knowledge gap.
No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of treating wastewater from intensive livestock holdings on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of reducing pesticide, herbicide or fertilizer use on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of establishing riparian buffers to reduce pollutant runoff on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of creating artificial wetlands to reduce effluent reaching water bodies on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of setting or improving minimum sewage treatment standards on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of limiting storm wastewater overflow on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of establishing aquaculture to extract nutrients from agricultural runoffs on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
No studies were found evaluating the regulation of agrichemical use specifically for marine mammals.
No studies were found evaluating limiting storm wastewater overflow specifically for marine mammals.
The lack of studies means there is currently no evidence to indicate whether pollution reduction actions are effective or have any harmful impacts on marine and freshwater mammal populations.

question_details.query: What are the most beneficial interventions for reducing marine mammal bycatch in Australian fisheries?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the evidence found, the most beneficial interventions for reducing marine mammal bycatch in Australian fisheries include: (1) Establishing handling and release protocols for captured mammals - a before-and-after study in the Great Australian Bight found this reduced mortality of short-beaked common dolphins when combined with avoiding dolphins during fishing (Action ID: 2829); (2) Deploying fishing gear at different depths - a controlled study in the Arafura Sea found nets deployed 4.5m below surface had fewer dolphin entanglements than surface nets (Action ID: 2793); (3) Establishing 'move-on rules' for fishing vessels when mammals are encountered - a before-and-after study in the Great Australian Bight found this resulted in fewer short-beaked common dolphins being encircled and killed when combined with releasing trapped dolphins (Action ID: 2790); (4) Using acoustic devices on fishing vessels - multiple studies including in Australian waters (Rainbow Channel and Keppel Bay) showed these can reduce dolphin foraging and echolocation activity, though effects vary by species and behavior type (Action ID: 2815); (5) Using catch and hook protection devices - studies show these can reduce unwanted catches of toothed whales and damage to fish catches (Action ID: 2821); and (6) Using acoustically reflective fishing gear materials - some studies found these materials reduced harbor porpoise entanglements, though results vary by material and species (Action ID: 2807). Several interventions like gear exchange programs, low-interest loans for gear conversion, and fisher involvement in gear design have been proposed but lack evaluation studies to confirm their effectiveness.
summary_statements: Establishing handling and release protocols for captured mammals is a beneficial intervention for reducing marine mammal bycatch in Australian fisheries.
A study in the Great Australian Bight found that establishing handling and release protocols reduced mortality of short-beaked common dolphins when combined with avoiding dolphins during fishing.
Deploying fishing gear at different depths is a beneficial intervention for reducing marine mammal bycatch.
A controlled study in the Arafura Sea found that nets deployed 4.5 meters below the surface had fewer dolphin entanglements than surface nets.
Establishing 'move-on rules' for fishing vessels when mammals are encountered is a beneficial intervention for reducing bycatch.
A study in the Great Australian Bight found 'move-on rules' resulted in fewer short-beaked common dolphins being encircled and killed when combined with releasing trapped dolphins.
Using acoustic devices on fishing vessels is a beneficial intervention for reducing marine mammal bycatch.
Multiple studies in Australian waters, including Rainbow Channel and Keppel Bay, showed acoustic devices can reduce dolphin foraging and echolocation activity.
The effects of acoustic devices on marine mammals vary by species and behavior type.
Using catch and hook protection devices can reduce unwanted catches of toothed whales.
Using catch and hook protection devices can reduce damage to fish catches.
Using acoustically reflective fishing gear materials is an intervention for reducing marine mammal bycatch.
Some studies found acoustically reflective fishing gear materials reduced harbor porpoise entanglements.
The effectiveness of acoustically reflective fishing gear materials varies by material and species.
Interventions like gear exchange programs, low-interest loans for gear conversion, and fisher involvement in gear design have been proposed to reduce marine mammal bycatch.
The proposed interventions of gear exchange programs, low-interest loans for gear conversion, and fisher involvement in gear design lack evaluation studies to confirm their effectiveness.

question_details.query: How does the evidence for mitigating seal predation differ between aquaculture systems and wild fisheries?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The evidence for mitigating seal predation shows distinct approaches between aquaculture systems and wild fisheries. In aquaculture systems, there is documented evidence for several techniques: replacing anti-predator nets more frequently at salmon farms resulted in fewer salmon losses to harbour seal predation (action 2774), and using acoustic devices at salmon farms reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals and South American sea lions, though effectiveness varied with two of six studies showing no reduction in predation (action 2775). Translocating mammals away from aquaculture systems showed limited effectiveness, with more than half or nearly all of translocated Australian and New Zealand fur seals returning to salmon farms (action 2776). For wild fisheries, the evidence focuses on gear modifications: installing steel rods on lobster pots or metal frames on fishing pots reduced seal entrapments (action 2822), and installing wire grids or steel bars on fishing trap-nets or bag-nets, along with strengthened netting, reduced damage to salmon catches by seals and resulted in higher catches of undamaged salmon (action 2822). Other approaches like switching off artificial lighting at wild fisheries did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon (action 2825), and playing predator calls did not deter Cape fur seals from feeding on fish catches (action 2817). No studies were found on enforcing regulations to prevent harmful deterrents at wild fisheries (action 2779).
summary_statements: The evidence for mitigating seal predation shows distinct approaches between aquaculture systems and wild fisheries.
In aquaculture systems, replacing anti-predator nets more frequently at salmon farms resulted in fewer salmon losses to harbour seal predation.
Using acoustic devices at salmon farms reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals and South American sea lions.
The effectiveness of using acoustic devices at salmon farms to reduce seal predation varied, with two of six studies showing no reduction in predation.
Translocating mammals away from aquaculture systems showed limited effectiveness.
More than half or nearly all of translocated Australian and New Zealand fur seals returned to salmon farms.
For wild fisheries, evidence on mitigating seal predation focuses on gear modifications.
Installing steel rods on lobster pots or metal frames on fishing pots reduced seal entrapments.
Installing wire grids or steel bars on fishing trap-nets or bag-nets, along with strengthened netting, reduced damage to salmon catches by seals.
The use of wire grids, steel bars, and strengthened netting on fishing nets resulted in higher catches of undamaged salmon.
Switching off artificial lighting at wild fisheries did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon.
Playing predator calls did not deter Cape fur seals from feeding on fish catches.
No studies were found on enforcing regulations to prevent harmful deterrents at wild fisheries.
